subject: Story Time: Pip's Big Parade
title: Pip's Big Parade
body:
Pip's Big Parade

Hi Mom,

Meet Pip, a little elephant who worries his trumpet is too quiet. This story is all about finding confidence in being yourself—even if you're a little quieter than the rest.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Celebrate their unique volume. In a loud world, quiet children can feel overlooked. Remind your little one that their voice matters, no matter how soft it is. Sometimes the quietest observations are the most profound.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Lila & The Ocean Song
title: Lila & The Ocean Song
body:
Lila & The Ocean Song

Hi Parent,

Join Lila as she finds calm in the rhythm of the waves. This is a perfect story for winding down after a busy day.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Co-regulation is key. When your child is overwhelmed, their nervous system looks to yours for safety. Taking deep breaths together—like the ocean waves—calms you both down faster than words ever could.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Sleepy Moon
title: The Sleepy Moon
body:
The Sleepy Moon

Hi Mom,

The sun has set, and Mr. Moon is here to watch over us. Use this gentle tale to help your little one drift off to dreamland.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Routine brings security. A predictable bedtime ritual (bath, book, bed) signals to your child's brain that it's time to sleep, reducing bedtime battles and helping them feel safe.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Leo's Lost Roar
title: Leo's Lost Roar
body:
Leo's Lost Roar

Hi Parent,

Leo the Lion has lost his roar and found a squeak instead! A funny and touching story about handling frustration.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Name it to tame it. When big feelings take over (like Leo's frustration), help your child name the emotion. Saying 'You look frustrated' validates their experience and helps the 'roar' pass more quickly.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Sharing Tree
title: The Sharing Tree
body:
The Sharing Tree

Hi Mom,

Squirrel learns that apples taste better when shared with friends. A sweet lesson on the joy of giving.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Model, don't force. True generosity comes from seeing others give. Instead of forcing 'share!', try sharing your own snacks or toys with your child to show them how good it feels.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Ruby's Rainy Day
title: Ruby's Rainy Day
body:
Ruby's Rainy Day

Hi Parent,

Rainy days don't have to be gloomy. Watch Ruby find magic in the puddles!

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Embrace the mess. Puddle jumping looks messy to us, but to a child, it's pure sensory joy. Putting on old clothes and letting them get dirty builds resilience and happy memories.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Magic Paintbrush
title: The Magic Paintbrush
body:
The Magic Paintbrush

Hi Mom,

Sam's drawings are coming to life! Encourage your child's imagination with this creative adventure.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Process over product. When your child creates art, focus on their effort ('Look how hard you worked on those swirls!') rather than just the final picture. It builds a growth mindset.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Benny's Balloon Ride
title: Benny's Balloon Ride
body:
Benny's Balloon Ride

Hi Parent,

Float away with Benny on a giant red balloon. A story about seeing the world from a new perspective.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Change the scenery. When a day feels stuck or grumpy (for you or them), a change of environment—even just stepping outside or looking out a different window—can reset everyone's mood.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Detective Fox
title: Detective Fox
body:
Detective Fox

Hi Mom,

There's a mystery afoot! Who stole the pie? Join Detective Fox for a fun whodunit.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Ask curiosity questions. Instead of giving answers, ask 'What do you think happened?' Curiosity builds critical thinking and is a great antidote to anxiety.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Brave Little Firefly
title: The Brave Little Firefly
body:
The Brave Little Firefly

Hi Parent,

Flicker is a firefly afraid of the dark. See how he finds his own light when a friend needs help.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Validate fears. It's okay to be scared. Acknowledging your child's fear ('That shadow looks spooky to you') helps them feel understood and brave enough to face it.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Morning Sun Salutation
title: Morning Sun Salutation
body:
Morning Sun Salutation

Hi Mom,

Start the day with energy! This interactive story guides you through a fun morning stretch.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Move to connect. Physical movement releases tension and boosts mood. Doing a quick stretch or dance party together in the morning connects you before the rush of the day begins.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Grumpy Cloud
title: The Grumpy Cloud
body:
The Grumpy Cloud

Hi Parent,

Gary the Cloud is holding in all his rain. Learn why having a good cry can make everything feel lighter.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Tears are healing. Crying isn't 'bad behavior'—it's a release valve for stress. Let your child cry without distracting them, and watch how much calmer they are afterwards.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Percy the Puffin’s Polar Picnic
title: Percy the Puffin’s Polar Picnic
body:
Percy the Puffin’s Polar Picnic

Hi Mom,

Meet Percy, a puffin who loves warmth in a very cold world. This story is all about finding your own sunshine, even when things feel a bit chilly or scary.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Perspective is a superpower. Help your child see that while we can't change the weather, we can always change our gear and our attitude. A warm scarf and a thermos of cocoa go a long way!


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Daisy the Daydreamer Dragon
title: Daisy the Daydreamer Dragon
body:
Daisy the Daydreamer Dragon

Hi Parent,

Daisy might have her head in the clouds, but her mindful ears save the day! a beautiful lesson in staying present and unique talents.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Daydreaming is deep work. When your child is staring off into space, they are often processing complex ideas. Instead of snapping them out of it, ask 'What's happening in your imagination right now?'


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Finley the Finicky Frog
title: Finley the Finicky Frog
body:
Finley the Finicky Frog

Hi Mom,

Finley is very picky about his food, until a little rainbow of flavor changes everything. Perfect for your little explorers!

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Pressure-free tasting. For picky eaters, the goals is curiosity, not consumption. Let them lick, smell, or just look at new foods without the pressure to eat it all.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Night-Light Knight
title: The Night-Light Knight
body:
The Night-Light Knight

Hi Parent,

Sir Leo Brave turns scary shadows into a game of tag. A must-read for peaceful bedtimes.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Empower their nighttime space. Letting your child 'patrol' the room with a flashlight or choose their own nightlight gives them a sense of agency over their environment.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Nervous Newt
title: The Nervous Newt
body:
The Nervous Newt

Hi Mom,

Ned is scared of his first swim class. Watch him find his courage.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Preview new experiences. Talk through what will happen before a new event (like swim class). Knowing what to expect reduces anxiety greatly.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Forgetful Squirrel
title: The Forgetful Squirrel
body:
The Forgetful Squirrel

Hi Parent,

Nutty can't find his acorns, but he finds adventure instead!

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Laugh at the chaos. Parenting is full of forgotten items and lost shoes. Using humor instead of anger diffuses tension for everyone.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Colorless Rainbow
title: The Colorless Rainbow
body:
The Colorless Rainbow

Hi Mom,

Ray the Rainbow has lost his colors. Help him find them in this bright tale.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Notice the beauty. pointing out small beautiful things (a flower, a cloud) teaches mindfulness and appreciation naturally.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Whispering Willow
title: The Whispering Willow
body:
The Whispering Willow

Hi Parent,

Trees have stories too. Listen to the wisdom of the old Willow.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Nature heals. Even 10 minutes near a tree or on the grass can lower cortisol levels for both you and your child.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Barnaby's Big Bake
title: Barnaby's Big Bake
body:
Barnaby's Big Bake

Hi Mom,

Barnaby uses salt instead of sugar! A delicious disaster story to giggle at.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Cook together. It's messy, yes. But it teaches math, science, and sensory skills—and kids endure eating food they helped make!


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Moon's Night Light
title: The Moon's Night Light
body:
The Moon's Night Light

Hi Parent,

The Moon leaves a light on for us. A comforting thought for the dark night.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Respect night fears. A nightlight isn't a crutch; it's a tool for comfort. Whatever helps them sleep safely is a win.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Lost Mitten
title: The Lost Mitten
body:
The Lost Mitten

Hi Mom,

One mitten warms many friends. A cozy winter tale.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Warmth is love. Physical warmth (hugs, cozy blankets) mimics emotional warmth. Snuggle up while reading!


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Grateful Garden
title: The Grateful Garden
body:
The Grateful Garden

Hi Parent,

The garden says thank you. A story to inspire gratitude.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Daily Gratitude. Ask 'What made you smile today?' at dinner. It wires the brain to look for the good.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: Professor Paws
title: Professor Paws
body:
Professor Paws

Hi Mom,

School is in session for the puppies! Join Professor Paws for a lesson.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Playful learning. Kids learn best through play, not drills. Chase, hide-and-seek, and pretend play ARE 'school' for young brains.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Boy Who Flew
title: The Boy Who Flew
body:
The Boy Who Flew

Hi Parent,

Timmy believes he can fly. And in his dreams, he does!

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Support the fantasy. Don't rush to correct their imagination. Magic and belief are distinct developing stages of childhood.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Underwater Tea Party
title: The Underwater Tea Party
body:
The Underwater Tea Party

Hi Mom,

Tea with an octopus? Why not!

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Say 'Yes' to the weird. If they want to wear a costume to the grocery store or have tea in the bath, why not? These are the memories that stick.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Dragon Who Loved Flowers
title: The Dragon Who Loved Flowers
body:
The Dragon Who Loved Flowers

Hi Parent,

Drake isn't a scary dragon. He's a gardener. A story about breaking molds.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Challenge stereotypes. Encourage your child to like what they like—whether it's trucks, dolls, mud, or sparkles—regardless of gender norms.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Clock That Ticked Backwards
title: The Clock That Ticked Backwards
body:
The Clock That Ticked Backwards

Hi Mom,

Time is a tricky thing. Travel back with Grandpa's clock.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Cherish the 'Now'. The days are long but the years are short. Take a photo of a mundane moment today.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Invisible Cat
title: The Invisible Cat
body:
The Invisible Cat

Hi Parent,

Whiskers is gone! Or is he? A fun game of hide and seek.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Object Permanence. Games like peek-a-boo and hide-and-seek help young children understand that you come back when you leave.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Lonely Scarecrow
title: The Lonely Scarecrow
body:
The Lonely Scarecrow

Hi Mom,

Even scarecrows need friends.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Friendship skills. Role-play how to introduce yourself to a new friend with your stuffed animals. It helps shy kids feel prepared.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Star That Fell
title: The Star That Fell
body:
The Star That Fell

Hi Parent,

From the sky to the sea, we all belong somewhere.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Belonging. Create family traditions (like Friday pizza night) to foster a deep sense of belonging for your child.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Very Loud Library
title: The Very Loud Library
body:
The Very Loud Library

Hi Mom,

Shhh! Or maybe not?

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Volume control. Play the 'Loud and Quiet' game to teach volume regulation in a fun way, rather than constantly shushing.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Cloud Castle
title: The Cloud Castle
body:
The Cloud Castle

Hi Parent,

Giants just want to play too.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Don't judge a book. Teacher your child to look for the kindness in others, even if they seem different or intimidating at first.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Train to Nowhere
title: The Train to Nowhere
body:
The Train to Nowhere

Hi Mom,

Ride the Dream Train tonight.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Dream talk. Ask your child what they want to dream about before they sleep. It sets a positive tone for the night.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Girl with Green Hair
title: The Girl with Green Hair
body:
The Girl with Green Hair

Hi Parent,

Ivy stands out in a crowd. And she loves it.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Self-Love. Affirm your child's physical traits. 'I love your curly hair,' 'I love your strong legs.' It builds body positivity early.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Robot Who Had Feelings
title: The Robot Who Had Feelings
body:
The Robot Who Had Feelings

Hi Mom,

Beep boop... I love you.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Emotional Intelligence. Use a feelings chart or just name emotions throughout the day. 'I feel happy because...'. Robots might learn it, but kids live it.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Missing Shadow
title: The Missing Shadow
body:
The Missing Shadow

Hi Parent,

Peter's shadow is being tricky.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Shadow Play. Go outside and play with shadows! It's great science learning (light and blockers) and pure fun.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Ants' Picnic
title: The Ants' Picnic
body:
The Ants' Picnic

Hi Mom,

Teamwork makes the dream work!

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Chores as Teamwork. Frame cleanup as 'Teamwork time!' instead of a chore. 'Let's see how fast our team can clear the floor!'


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Paper Boat Journey
title: The Paper Boat Journey
body:
The Paper Boat Journey

Hi Parent,

Small boats embark on big journeys.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Letting go. It's hard to watch them drift away (even just to preschool). Trust that you've built them a strong enough boat.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Friendly Ghost
title: The Friendly Ghost
body:
The Friendly Ghost

Hi Mom,

Casper wants a playdate.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Inclusivity. Talk about including the kid who is sitting alone. Kindness is a muscle we exercise.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Snowman's Summer
title: The Snowman's Summer
body:
The Snowman's Summer

Hi Parent,

Impossible dreams can come true.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Dream Big. Never stifle a 'crazy' dream. If they want to be an astronaut-ballerina, help them find the helmet and the tutu.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Talking Toaster
title: The Talking Toaster
body:
The Talking Toaster

Hi Mom,

Start your day with a laugh.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Humor is survival. When everything is going wrong (spilled milk, tantrums), try to find the funny side. It breaks the stress cycle.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Boy Who Ate The Moon
title: The Boy Who Ate The Moon
body:
The Boy Who Ate The Moon

Hi Parent,

Is the moon made of crackers?

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Snack curiosity. Involve them in food choices. 'What shape should our sandwiches be today?' Autonomy reduces pickiness.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Secret Door
title: The Secret Door
body:
The Secret Door

Hi Mom,

Magic is hidden in the corners.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Secret Spaces. Kids love small nooks (forts, under tables). It makes them feel big and in control. Let them build one!


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Musical Forest
title: The Musical Forest
body:
The Musical Forest

Hi Parent,

The world is singing.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Listen. Go for a 'Listening Walk'. Stop and identify 5 sounds. It grounds you both in the present moment.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Kangaroo with No Pouch
title: The Kangaroo with No Pouch
body:
The Kangaroo with No Pouch

Hi Mom,

There's no one 'right' way to be a mom.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

You are enough. Kiki finds her own way, and so do you. Don't compare your parenting journey to others.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The City of Sweets
title: The City of Sweets
body:
The City of Sweets

Hi Parent,

A delicious dream.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Treats are okay. labeling food as 'good' or 'bad' can create issues. Food is fuel AND fun. Enjoy the treat together without guilt.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The Owl Who Slept at Night
title: The Owl Who Slept at Night
body:
The Owl Who Slept at Night

Hi Mom,

Owen does things differently.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Rhythms. Some kids are night owls, some are early birds. Working WITH their natural rhythm instead of fighting it saves so much energy.


Read the full story

subject: Story Time: The End of the Rainbow
title: The End of the Rainbow
body:
The End of the Rainbow

Hi Parent,

The treasure was us all along.

Ms. Erica's Parenting Tip

Connect. The greatest gift you give your child is your presence. Put down the phone for 5 minutes of pure connection today.


Read the full story
